author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 12, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: For Many in Rafah, Displacement Is a Recurring Nightmare
description: More than a million people fled repeatedly before landing in Gaza’s southernmost city, and now they and the city’s residents are wondering where they could possibly go next.
content: Less than two weeks after bombs began raining down on the Gaza Strip, Ghada al-Kurd arrived in the southern city of Khan Younis. She had already been displaced three times, and hoped it would be her final journey to safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Raja Abdulrahim, Hiba Yazbek and Ben Shpigel
title: Terrified Gazans Await an Israeli Advance in the City They Fled To
description: Israel has asked the military to come up with plans to evacuate Gazans, but it isn’t clear where they are supposed to go or when Israel’s ground invasion might begin.
content: Petrified Gazans in the cramped southern border city of Rafah scrambled to evade bombardment on Saturday as they prepared to flee an expected Israeli ground offensive, dreading the prospect of again searching for safety in a place with few, if any, options to escape the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Nikki Haley denounces Trump’s NATO comments and defends her husband against his attacks.
description: “Don’t take the side of a thug who kills his opponents,” Ms. Haley said on CBS’s “Face the Nation” on Sunday, after Donald Trump suggested he might encourage Russia to attack a NATO member.
content: Nikki Haley condemned former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday for suggesting that he might not defend NATO allies, and that he might even encourage Russia to attack them, if re-elected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Kisner, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Rowan Niemisto and Andrea Vancura
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Unthinkable Mental Health Crisis That Shook a New England College’
description: Over six terrible months, professors and administrators at Worcester Polytechnic Institute took on the unofficial role of counselors during a spate of campus suicides.
content: The first death happened before the academic year began. In July 2021, an undergraduate student at Worcester Polytechnic Institute was reported dead. The administration sent a notice out over email, with the familiar, thoroughly vetted phrasing and appended resources. Katherine Foo, an assistant professor in the department of integrative and global studies, felt especially crushed by the news. She taught this student. He was Chinese, and she felt connected to the particular set of pressures he faced. She read through old, anonymous course evaluations, looking for any sign she might have missed. But she was unsure where to put her personal feelings about a loss suffered in this professional context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: This Real Estate Kingpin Maps Out the Path to Megadeals
description: Widely considered the top commercial sales broker in New York City, the largest commercial market in the country, Bob Knakal’s deals total $22 billion — and counting.
content: The best view of New York City might just be in a near-windowless conference room on the 12th floor of a Midtown Manhattan office building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Special Counsel Report ‘Went Off the Rails,’ Biden’s Lawyer Says
description: Allies and White House officials defended the president after the release of a report that cleared him of criminal wrongdoing in a classified documents case but raised new concerns about his age.
content: White House officials and Democrats fanned out to defend President Biden’s mental fitness on Sunday, reflecting the rising anxiety in the president’s administration over a special counsel report that fueled concern about his age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: The Rise, and Fall, and Rise Again of Imran Khan
description: Mr. Khan’s success was fueled by social media, which drove Pakistan’s young people to turn out to vote and rebuff the country’s powerful military.
content: When Pakistan’s government censored the media, former Prime Minister Imran Khan’s party posted campaign videos on TikTok. When the police barred his supporters from holding rallies, they hosted virtual gatherings online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: ‘This Is Where I Want to Be’
description: Kibbutz Kfar Azza was evacuated after more than 60 residents were murdered and at least 18 were kidnapped on Oct. 7. But one family has returned.
content: When Ayelet Khon moved back to the Kfar Azza kibbutz with her husband two months after the brutal Hamas-led attack of Oct. 7, the first thing she did was hang a string of rainbow-colored lights up on the front patio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Rubio defends Trump’s NATO comments with an old line: ‘He doesn’t talk like a traditional politician.’
description: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, suggested there was nothing the former president could say that would shake Mr. Rubio’s support.
content: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, on Sunday brushed aside former President Donald J. Trump’s comments suggesting that he might not defend NATO allies and that he would encourage Russia to “do whatever the hell they want.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Johanna Lemola
title: Finland Elects Alexander Stubb President as It Ushers in NATO Era
description: The election of the center-right politician fills a role that is responsible for foreign policy in an era of rising wariness of neighboring Russia.
content: Finns elected the center-right politician Alexander Stubb as their new president on Sunday, in the first national election since the country joined NATO, filling a post that will be critical to shaping Finland’s role in the alliance at a time of increasingly fraught relations with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Orlando Mayorquin and J. David Goodman
title: Boy Is Critically Wounded in Shooting at Houston Church Led by Joel Osteen
description: A woman entered the Lakewood Church, a megachurch in Houston, with a rifle and opened fire, officials said. Off-duty officers shot and killed her.
content: A boy was critically injured on Sunday afternoon after a woman opened fire at a Christian megachurch in Houston led by Joel Osteen, the televangelist and pastor, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Long Cylindrical Instrument
description: Jess Shulman and Amie Walker raise a few eyebrows.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Short on Soldiers, Ukraine Debates How to Find the Next Wave of Troops
description: A potential expansion of the nation’s military draft to replenish the exhausted, battered army has become an emotional, politically charged issue.
content: Soldiers fight in freezing, muddy trenches bombarded by artillery, or in warrens of burned and blown-up houses in urban combat. Casualty rates are high, and dangerous missions, like storming enemy-held tree lines, abound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Filming ‘Virginia Woolf,’ the Battles Weren’t Just Onscreen
description: With Burton and Taylor as stars and a writer and director feuding, adapting the scabrous play wasn’t easy. “Cocktails With George and Martha” pours out the details.
content: What a document dump!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: At the Puppy Bowl, Extra Points for Being a Very Good Boy
description: The other big game on Super Bowl Sunday? The 20th outing of Animal Planet’s football game for puppies (complete with a kitten halftime show).
content: It’s frowned upon when N.F.L. players complain to the referees. But at least they don’t urinate on them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Maya King
title: Black Churches in Georgia Unite to Mobilize Voters in a Key Battleground
description: Two of the state’s largest church groups are teaming up in a rare effort they say is motivated by this year’s stakes and new voting restrictions in Georgia.
content: Two of the largest Black church groups in Georgia are formally uniting for the first time to mobilize Black voters in the battleground state ahead of the November presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Taylor Swift’s Journey to Las Vegas Ends With Super Bowl Win
description: The pop singer had to travel across the globe (and through time, in a sense) to make the game. She watched Travis Kelce and Kansas City beat San Francisco in overtime.
content: The Kansas City Chiefs won their third Super Bowl title in the last five seasons by beating the San Francisco 49ers in overtime, 25-22, on Sunday. While some N.F.L. players go their entire career without winning a championship, one of Kansas City’s newcomers came away a winner in their 13th game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Christopher Nolan, Robert Downey Jr. and Missed Connections
description: These Oscar nominees for “Oppenheimer” met years ago, but the director had no plans to cast this star then, noting, “I was also a little afraid of you.”
content: Christopher Nolan and Robert Downey Jr. have each worked on some of the most lucrative and beloved superhero films of our time, many of them with enormous star-filled casts, so how is it that the two had never worked together on a movie before now, superhero or otherwise?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: An Old Cowtown Fancies Its Time in the Limelight
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 11, 2024.
content: “We’re not New York or Chicago, but we’re getting there. We’re showing people that we have cool stuff going on here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: New Historical Fiction That Immerses You in Far-Flung Places
description: From England and France to the deepest Arctic and northern China, these stories will transport you.
content: Anne Michaels has served as Toronto’s poet laureate, so it’s no surprise that her latest novel, HELD (Knopf, 240 pp., $27), turns a multigenerational family saga into a lyrical jigsaw of images and observations, a trigger to “the long fuse of memory, always alight.” It begins in the trenches of World War I with a soldier’s impressions of what’s essentially a “450-mile grave” and ends in the near future as one of his descendants walks the streets of a city on the Gulf of Finland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: What Happens When TikTok Is Your Marketing Department
description: The Pink Stuff, a home cleaning paste, went from total obscurity to viral sensation — and Walmart staple — thanks to one “cleanfluencer” and her legion of fans.
content: In 2018, The Pink Stuff was little more than a home cleaning product with a cute name. “The miracle cleaning paste,” as it said on every container, was sold by just two retail chains in Britain. At a factory near Birmingham, The Pink Stuff line operated for about two hours every month. That was plenty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: ‘Kill B.’ Review: Dances of Dominance
description: In this work, inspired by Quentin Tarantino’s “Kill Bill” films, Croatian performers address the fraught director-actress relationship at its core.
content: The dancer Mia Zalukar lay collapsed on the stage of NYU Skirball, seemingly exhausted after a long solo — but she wasn’t doing it quite right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: ‘It Is Suffocating’: A Top Liberal University Is Under Attack in India
description: A campaign to make the country an explicitly Hindu nation has had a chilling effect on left-leaning and secular institutions like Jawaharlal Nehru University.
content: Jawaharlal Nehru University, named for India’s first prime minister, is one of the country’s premier liberal institutions, a hothouse of strong opinions and left-leaning values whose graduates populate the upper echelons of academia and government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Pakistan’s Stunning Election Results
description: Also, Donald Trump derides NATO and the U.S. prepares to watch the Super Bowl.
content: Candidates aligned with the party of the imprisoned former Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan won the most seats in Pakistan’s parliamentary elections, despite the military’s efforts to suppress support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Imran Khan’s ‘Victory Speech’ From Jail Shows A.I.’s Peril and Promise
description: It was not the first time the technology had been used in Pakistan’s notably repressive election season, but this time it got the world’s attention.
content: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s former prime minister, has spent the duration of the country’s electoral campaign in jail, disqualified from running in what experts have described as one of the least credible general elections in the country’s 76-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Space Parasol Folly
description: A response to an article about building a space umbrella to shield Earth from the sun. Also: The migrant crisis.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Mayorkas Says He’s Undeterred by Republicans’ Impeachment Drive
description: The homeland security secretary called the allegations “baseless” and said he was focused on his work.
content: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, said on Sunday that he was not dwelling on congressional Republicans’ continued efforts to impeach him over his handling of the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘One Day, I Stepped Out of My Building as She Was Walking Past’
description: A shared fashion sense in Brooklyn, a ride in a Checker cab and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Hate Valentine’s Day? There’s a Market for You, Too.
description: Single, anti-consumerist or just not a romantic? From petty heartbreak healers to anti-Valentine’s Day parties, groups are finding ways to resonate with naysayers.
content: Lilly Calman is not in the mood this Valentine’s Day for the flowers, chocolates or a romantic dinner for two, especially after a recent breakup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Christopher Nolan Wins DGA Award, Putting Him on Track for the Oscar
description: After four losses, this is the first guild victory for the “Oppenheimer” director. Winners there have won the Academy Award 18 of the last 20 times.
content: The Directors Guild of America on Saturday night handed its top prize for feature-film directing to Christopher Nolan for his hit biopic, “Oppenheimer,” starring Cillian Murphy as the physicist who helped design the atomic bomb. This is the latest major trophy Nolan’s film has won, after taking top honors from the Golden Globes and Critics Choice Awards last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: How Do You Get Acoustic Instruments to Play Electronic Music?
description: The composer Matthew Sheeran, brother of the pop star Ed Sheeran, discusses how he translated microtonal electronic music for a chamber orchestra.
content: If you start at the middle C of a piano and strike every key on your way up to the next C on the keyboard, you will play each of the 12 notes that make up an octave. Those 12 semitones are the foundation of most Western music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Ukraine-Israel Aid Bill Clears Critical Hurdle in the Senate
description: The bipartisan vote to advance the measure put it on track for passage, but its fate in the House remains uncertain amid stiff G.O.P. opposition, egged on by former President Donald J. Trump.
content: The Senate on Sunday pushed a $95 billion emergency aid bill for Ukraine and Israel past a critical hurdle, with a bipartisan vote that kept it on track for passage within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: King Charles Appears in Public for First Time Since Cancer Announcement
description: The British monarch and Queen Camilla went for a brief walk to a church on the estate where they live. Buckingham Palace said last week that the king was being treated for an unspecified form of cancer.
content: King Charles III on Sunday was seen publicly for the first time since Buckingham Palace announced last week that he was being treated for cancer, strolling into a church on the royal Sandringham estate where he has his residence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Chili for the Championship
description: With bulgogi-style tofu for Monday and crispy baked fish for Tuesday.
content: Many will make chili (above) today, one of the great foods of National Football League cuisine, up there with wings and nachos. Ali Slagle’s recipe is top-drawer: deep in flavor, spice and smokiness, and fairly easy to prepare. I like to make it with coarsely ground beef from the butcher instead of the more finely cut stuff you get at the supermarket, but that’s just me being fancy. Make it with whatever meat you like — so long as it’s decently fatty, to bring out the taste of the aromatics. Chili’s a good way to guarantee a win during the Super Bowl, whichever team you’re rooting for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Sosnik
title: Biden Can’t Count on Trump’s Unpopularity Anymore
description: If Biden can’t convince enough voters that he is up to the presidency into his mid-80s, it doesn’t matter how the country feels about Trump.
content: The low approval rating and various political headwinds for President Biden have invited comparisons with another first-term Democratic president, Jimmy Carter, and the challenges he faced running for re-election in 1980. Many Republicans are thinking about his defeat at the hands of Ronald Reagan, bullish that Donald Trump also has what it takes to oust a flagging incumbent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Ellen Gilchrist, Writer With an Eye on the South’s Foibles, Dies at 88
description: In her novels and story collections, she took a sharp, lightly ironic look at the class from which she came, the Southern upper bourgeoisie.
content: Ellen Gilchrist, a Southern writer with a sharp, sometimes indulgent eye for her region’s foibles and eccentricities, died on Jan. 30 at her home in Ocean Springs, Miss. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: An Outburst by Trump on NATO May Push Europe to Go It Alone
description: Many were alarmed by comments that he would “encourage” Russia to attack U.S. allies that didn’t pay into NATO, but European leaders were already pondering the prospect of an alliance without the United States.
content: Long before Donald J. Trump threatened over the weekend that he was willing to let Russia “do whatever the hell they want” against NATO allies that do not contribute sufficiently to collective defense, European leaders were quietly discussing how they might prepare for a world in which America removes itself as the centerpiece of the 75-year-old alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Cautions Netanyahu on Ground Offensive in Southern Gaza
description: The president told the Israeli leader on Sunday that protection was needed for Palestinians seeking shelter and called for “urgent and specific” steps on humanitarian aid.
content: President Biden warned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday that a ground offensive in southern Gaza should not proceed without a plan to protect the more than 1.4 million Palestinians clustered there, the latest sign of frustration by the White House over rising civilian deaths from Israel’s military assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Austin Taken to Hospital for Bladder Issue
description: The Pentagon said the White House, the Joint Chiefs and Congress had been notified of the defense secretary’s condition, unlike when he kept complications from prostate surgery secret last month.
content: The Pentagon announced on Sunday that Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been taken that afternoon to a military hospital to be treated for “symptoms suggesting an emergent bladder issue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Migrants Face Cold, Perilous Crossing From Canada to New York
description: Increasingly, migrants from Latin America are risking their lives to cross illegally into the United States along the northern border.
content: In a dilapidated farm shed in New York’s rural North Country, the belongings of a migrant family who quietly took shelter one night were still visible months later: some clothing and children’s shoes, stiffened by the cold and a thin blanket of snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Steve Ostrow, Manhattan Bathhouse Impresario, Dies at 91
description: The Continental Baths, which he opened in 1968, became a pivot point in Manhattan’s gay history and a launchpad for a young Bette Midler.
content: Steve Ostrow, the founder of the Continental Baths — an extravagant gay men’s sex club and performance space that flourished at the turn of the 1970s in the basement of the Ansonia Hotel, a Beaux-Arts landmark on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, and launched the careers of Bette Midler and Barry Manilow — died on Feb. 3 at his home in Sydney, Australia. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: What MAGA Influencers Are Missing About Football
description: The politics around the N.F.L. have gotten weird. Jane Coaston interviews Charles C.W. Cooke about football’s singular appeal and what MAGA influencers don’t understand.
content: More than 100 million people are expected to watch this Sunday’s Super Bowl between the Kansas City Chiefs and the San Francisco 49ers, most likely making it the year’s most watched television broadcast — again. The National Football League is an American cultural behemoth: Ninety-three of 2023’s 100 most-watched television broadcasts were N.F.L. games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Andrés R. Martínez and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Israel Says It Will Protect Civilians in a Gazan City It Is Determined to Invade
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that Israel would invade refugee-packed Rafah, but was drafting a plan to help people get out of harm’s way.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, brushing aside a chorus of international condemnation, said Sunday that a ground invasion of the southern Gazan city of Rafah would move forward as soon as Israel completed plans for the more than a million people sheltering there to be allowed to move to safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Lost at Parkland: ‘Peter Was Always My Translator’
description: For one family, grieving the child they lost in the Parkland, Fla., school shooting is complicated by differences in language and culture.
content: Linda Zhang wandered into her son’s room and sat for a while. She visits there from time to time, after her husband has gone to work at the restaurant and their other kids have gone to school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patti Davis
title: My Father, Ronald Reagan, Would Weep for America
description: I used to resent his love for America. Now it’s what I miss most of all.
content: The night before my father, Ronald Reagan, died, I listened to his breathing — ragged, thin. Nothing like that of the athletic man who rode horses, built fences at the ranch, constructed jumps from old phone poles, cut back shrubs along riding trails. Or of the man who lifted his voice to the overcast sky and said, “Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Election Shocker in Pakistan: Where the Country Goes From Here
description: As supporters of Imran Khan lodge complaints of vote rigging in hopes of increasing their lead, his opponents are jockeying to form a government.
content: Imran Khan’s stunning performance in Pakistan’s national election has upended most traditional political forecasts in a country where leaders who run afoul of the powerful military rarely find electoral success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Brian McConnachie, Humor Writer ‘From Another Planet,’ Dies at 81
description: A contributor to National Lampoon, “Saturday Night Live” and “SCTV,” he had a patrician presence that belied a whimsical and sometimes anarchic wit.
content: Brian McConnachie, who brought absurdist humor to three comedy touchstones of the 1970s and ’80s — National Lampoon magazine and the NBC television series “Saturday Night Live” and “SCTV Network” — died in hospice care on Jan. 5 in Venice, Fla. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Morning Team
title: A Guide to the Super Bowl
description: We explain the teams, the halftime show, the prop bets and more.
content: Nothing brings together more Americans — not awards shows, not television series finales, not even presidential debates — than the Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate LoPresti, Tina Antolini, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez and Callie Holtermann
title: Behind the Scenes of the Puppy Bowl
description: The real big game this Sunday.
content: This Sunday, adorable and adoptable players will face off in the 20th annual Puppy Bowl. Over the past two decades, this Animal Planet show has risen in popularity, becoming a ratings juggernaut. It has also grown in complexity: It is now a sophisticated production that involves more than 100 staff members (and approximately 200 poop bags).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Yes, Biden’s Age Matters
description: The confusion and forgetfulness vividly described in the special counsel Robert Hur’s report are not going away.
content: One of the most difficult conversations you can have in life is with a parent or peer who is becoming too old and infirm to work. Whether the infirmity is physical or mental, often your loved one is the last person to realize his own deficiencies, so he may interpret respectful, genuine concern as a personal attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Latino, Working Class and Proud
description: A friendship forged in a Las Vegas barbershop offers clues to one of the biggest questions of the presidential election: Can Democrats win back Latino men?
content: Daniel Trujillo and Paul Madrid took over the Eastside Cutters barbershop more than 20 years ago, just a few miles from the casinos of the Las Vegas Strip, where they both once worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Says He Gave NATO Allies Warning: Pay In or He’d Urge Russian Aggression
description: Speaking in Conway, S.C., Donald J. Trump said as president he had told NATO allies that he would urge Russian aggression against countries that had not met unofficial financial commitments.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Saturday that, while president, he told the leaders of NATO countries that he would “encourage” Russia “to do whatever the hell they want” to countries that had not paid the money they owed to the military alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: The Super Bowl Ads, Ranked
description: Here is how our critic saw the Super Bowl commercials from best to worst.
content: In the spirit of “Who actually watches the game?,” here is our ranking of Sunday night’s Super Bowl commercials, from best to worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Favoring Foes Over Friends, Trump Threatens to Upend International Order
description: Former President Donald J. Trump suggested that he would incite Russia to attack “delinquent” U.S. allies, foreshadowing potentially far-reaching changes in the world order if he wins the White House again.
content: Soon after former President Donald J. Trump took office, his staff explained how NATO’s mutual defense obligations worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli Analysts Say Rafah Invasion Is Unlikely to Be Imminent
description: A major challenge for Israeli forces will be how to move the more than 1 million Gazans who have crowded into the city out of harm’s way.
content: Israeli leaders have framed an invasion of the southern Gaza city of Rafah as an imperative to achieve its goal of eliminating Hamas. But it’s a strategy that is fraught with complexity and is generating criticism over the potentially catastrophic impact such an operation would have on the more than 1 million Gazans sheltering there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is This the Future of New York Fashion?
description: Khaite has awards, fans and momentum — but there’s something missing.
content: By almost any measure, Khaite, the women’s wear label founded in 2016 by Catherine Holstein, is one of the great recent success stories of American fashion — if not the great success story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Feel a Bit Like Gulliver’: Peek Inside a 100-Year-Old Royal Dolls’ House
description: At a time of turmoil for Britain’s royal family, an exhibition at Windsor Castle provides an insight into the lives of an earlier king and queen.
content: The silver crown is set with diamonds. Rubies, sapphires, emeralds and seed pearls are peppered through the design. And the red velvet cap inside would be fit to cushion the head of a monarch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 11, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 11, 2024.
content: An article on Feb. 4 about the founding of Israel incorrectly identified Jorge Garcia Granados. He was the Guatemalan ambassador to the United Nations, not the foreign minister of Guatemala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Congressman Who Broke With G.O.P. on Mayorkas Vote Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Representative Mike Gallagher of Wisconsin, once seen as a rising star, made the announcement just days after voting against impeaching the homeland security secretary.
content: Representative Mike Gallagher, Republican of Wisconsin, announced on Saturday that he would not run for re-election, just days after breaking with his party to cast a decisive vote against impeachment charges for Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: The Planet Needs Solar Power. Can We Build It Without Harming Nature?
description: Today’s decisions about how and where to set up new energy projects will reverberate for generations.
content: Today’s decisions about how and where to set up new energy projects will reverberate for generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Flynn
title: The Year of the Dragon Roars In
description: Here’s a look at celebrations around the world.
content: Here’s a look at celebrations around the world.
source.name: The New York Times
